awd_titl_txt: Full Characterization of a Cavity Electromagnetically Induced Transparency Based Quantum Gate
awd_abstract_narration:
The field of quantum information science is an intensely pursued research area due to the technological impact that a realized quantum computer would have. The availability of a trustworthy quantum processor would revamp numerous aspects of science and engineering, including the optimization of chemical reactions, the development of ultra-secure communication channels, and the materialization of powerful computers. After nearly twenty years of experimental research, technologies have emerged that may serve as the elementary building blocks for a quantum processor. Among these are technologies associated with the interaction of photons and atoms. The supported research group aims to develop a milestone towards building a quantum processor:  the realization of an interface between two single photons and atoms in a configuration designed to perform logic operations at the quantum level.

The goal of this work is to fully characterize a proof of principle system capable of a two-qubit operation using light. To accomplish this goal the supported research group will interface two of the most powerful tools in quantum optics; that of cavity quantum electrodynamics (cavity QED) for strong light-matter coupling and electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT) to allow control of large optical nonlinearities. The research program will pursue two primary objectives. First, the group will finish construction of the first experimental setup in which two cavities are coupled simultaneously to a 87Rb ensemble, thereby creating an interaction medium for two independent optical modes (qubits). Under EIT conditions, the cavity fields will experience an enhanced interaction strength permitting the observation of nonlinear effects using single-photon fields, the essential component of a quantum optical gate. Once achieved, the second objective is to fully characterize the gate operation using a technique known as coherent state quantum process tomography (csQPT). This tool allows the characterization of quantum optical processes, such as gates, using only coherent states which are readily available from a common laser source.

por.por_cntn:
In the work sponsored by this NSF grant, we have developed a vibrant research project, touching upon several aspects of quantum information distribution and processing using photonic qubits and entanglement, combined with rubidium atomic ensembles. Our main research directions were:

1) Creation of low-noise, high- fidelity quantum memories for qubits mediated by a high fidelity quantum interface based upon robust atomic collective excitations (DSP).

2) Design and implementation of sources of quantum light tuned to atomic transitions that are ready for interfacing with atomic ensembles.

3) Creation and full characterization of photon-photon Kerr non-linearities created in atomic ensembles.

Through the duration of the grant, opportunities were identified to use the techniques that were developed in the initial phases of the project to also pursue and study quantum system at room temperature. This was a major success as it allowed us to identify problems that could be tackled with room temperature quantum devices, such as the creation of large, scalable quantum networks.

At the end of the grant we developed unique capabilities, having developed scalable quantum memory systems and also quantum gate-like, non-linear atomic systems. This has positioned our research program as a world leader in the development of complex quantum networks of many interconnected quantum devices.

 Among our significant results, we mention:

1) Achieving room temperature quantum memories with fidelities higher that 98%

2) Demonstrating portable operation of a room temperature quantum memory.

3) Implementing of a communication quantum network using the BB84 quantum cryptography protocol and a quantum memory using a free space link.

4) Measuring coherent state quantum process tomography of a Kerr non-linearity using pulsed quantum homodyne tomography.

5) Designing and implementing a high rate of single-photons tuned to rubidium transitions.

6) Demonstrating first results regarding the coupling of two medium finesse cavities to a cold atomic ensemble.

 We envision the development of fully quantum operational room temperature quantum devices as a fundamental step towards building quantum technology that is commercially available. Our quantum interfaces operating at room temperature could be the basis for scalable quantum systems tackling important problems in quantum communication protocols such quantum cryptography and quantum repeaters.  

As stated by recent articles in The Economist and the New York Times, the quantum technology market is expected to grow considerably in the next ten years. We envision an incredible opportunity to used our developments to bridge the gap between laboratory implementations and all-environment devices that can be used in global communication.
